title: KKK recruitment flyers pop up in New Jersey town doorsteps
text:
Lyndhurst Police Ku Klux Klan recruitment fliers were distributed in Lyndhurst township over the weekend. Ku Klux Klan members are appealing to a fler power in New Jersey to recruit members.
Recruitment pamphlets from the hate group turned up on Lyndhurstâ€™s doorsteps and driveways last weekend.
The flyers asked neighbors to "Join the Klan and Save our Nation," and were stashed in clear sandwich bags with rocks to weigh them down, cops said.
The pamphlet also included a link to the KKK's White Knights page, and a phone number for the group in North Carolina.
The Knight's grand dragon Robert Jones said the neighborhood's Klansmen had a meeting where they decided to send out the recruitment flers. He said they wanted to let white people know they had "another alternative out there."
"The blacks have the NAACP. The Jews have the ADL and the JDL and the Southern Poverty Law Center. And whites, they've got no group working for their interest but the KKK," he told The Record.
JIM LO SCALZO/EPA The hate group has tried recruiting through fliers in other places as well, including the Hamptons, Georgia, South Carolina and Florida. There were five complaints about the hate group's recruitment tactic, police said. One neighbor collected all the flyers he could find and threw them out, according to reports.
Bergen County's NAACP president, Anthony Cureton, condemned the KKK's efforts.
The group has tried recruiting through pamphlets in the past, in places including the Hamptons , South Carolina , Florida and Georgia .
